Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the growth of union jobs in Texas compared to Illinois.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or data to support the statement about factory workers making more money in Texas than in Illinois.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the growth of union jobs in Texas is solely due to its right-to-work status, without considering other factors.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to consider alternative explanations for the differences in union job growth between Texas and Illinois, such as differences in industries or economic factors.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Illinois workers employed in the manufacturing sector make an average of $9,200 more per year than their counterparts in Indiana, which is a right-to-work state.
Falters at times: The claim falters by selectively comparing Texas to Illinois instead of comparing Illinois to neighboring Indiana, which is also a right-to-work state.
Understate: The claim may understate the impact of other factors, such as regulations and taxes, on the closure of the auto plant in Normal, Illinois.
